captions.text:
Have you ever had the feeling that there's
something bigger out there, something you

can't see? Well there is – it's called Dark
Matter.

Dark matter is spread throughout space, engulfing
the Milky Way and all other galaxies. It's

four times more common in the universe than
visible matter, yet we've never seen or directly

So how do we know it's there? Because of gravity.
A galaxy is like a giant merry-go-round that

all the stars are riding. In order to stay
on, each star has to hold on tight (that's

where gravity comes in), otherwise it'll fly
off into space.

The problem is, the force of gravity from
all the stars we can see isn't strong enough

to hold galaxies together – all the stars
should be flying off the edge of the merry-go-round!

But they're not. It's as if some invisible
rope is helping them hold on. Physicists believe

that rope is the gravitational force from
stuff we can't see - hence, Dark Matter.

And how do we know the speeds of stars in
distant galaxies? The doppler effect (which

is why a police siren shifts to a lower pitch
as the car passes) also works for light – that's

how radar catches you speeding, and how astronomers
measure the rotation of galaxies.

So, we use what we can see to tell us about
what we can't.

title: Minute Physics: What is Dark Matter?

comments.text:
OK, what I meant was the following, and I apologize for not being more 
descriptive in my original post.  The Higgs field gives everything mass, I 
think.  My simple brain can only think of this field like a sponge that is 
not very dense. small particles can move pretty freely, but larger 
structures with more mass are held more securely.  the faster you try to 
get through it the more difficult this is.  If the sponge is stationary, 
the travel through the invisible spongy material is at one speed and it is 
the same as what an outside observer would see.  If you rotate the sponge 
around the central axis of the galaxy so it would be moving with the stars, 
then the relative velocity of the stars would be less through the Higgs 
field.  Would this mean that they have less interaction with it and 
potentially less mass?  They could then orbit slower than they normally 
would have to?   Could this explain the observations in a more simple way 
than Dark matter that no one can see? 
I am not off my rocker, but I will admit that I am ignorant.  Sometimes 
though it is easier for an ignorant person to think outside the box. Heck, 
I don't even have a box.  Thanks everyone for discussing this.

December 31, 2013
2013 in review
By darkmatterdarkenergy

The scalar Higgs field suffers from the hierarchy problem: the Higgs mass 
and VEV are very sensitive to Ultraviolet (UV)
What is the relationship between the Higgs and dark matter? In an earlier 
blog, http://wp.me/p1mZmr-3K , I discussed why the Higgs particle itself 
cannot be the explanation for dark matter.  ------ Dark matter must be 
stable; ---- it must persist over the nearly 14 billion year lifetime of 
the universe. In today’s universe it’s very difficult and expensive to 
create a    
 ----Higgs particle and it vanishes immediately.---

I used little lines because you have problems reading.  Dark matter must be 
stable and the Higgs isn't stable.  

http://www.astro.umd.edu/~ssm/darkmatter/WIMPexperiments.html


It's called dark because we can't understand it yet.

Also, "transparent" matter would be misleading because it is not 
transparent. 

http://www.astro.umd.edu/~ssm/darkmatter/WIMPexperiments.html

Cold Dark Matter and Experimental Searches for WIMPs
Seeking WIMPs in all the wrong places
The Need for Dark Matter
Extragalactic systems like spiral galaxies and clusters of galaxies exhibit 
mass discrepancies. The application of Newton's Law of Gravity to the 
observed stars and gas fails to explain the rapid observed motions. This 
leads to the inference that some form of  
--- invisible mass - dark matter - - dominates the dynamics of the universe.

Another line to point out invisible matter is dark matter.

You had your say little boy. Now its time for you to go outside and play so 
the grownups can talk.

comments.text: +r2kordmaa Dark matter is a religion.
comments.author: James Briggs

comments.text:
+mikestoneadfjgs "only theoretical calculations that prove it must be 
there" Nope, nope, nope. That is not how scientific method works. You start 
out with a theory, in this case general relativity, based on that you 
predict how reality should behave if you were on right track, in this case 
how fast galaxies should rotate and then you go and test it, in this case 
measure how fast galaxies rotate. Reality matches your theory or it does 
not and the experiment is what tells us if we are right or wrong. In this 
case experiment tells us our prediction failed. So we are left with two 
possibilities, eighter we got the theory wrong or we got the experiment 
wrong. Because we do not have a better theory and the one we have works 
damn well everywhere else, we try to continue with the latter possibility, 
that we just got the measurement wrong. While "dark matter" does enable us 
to continue working on other things until we figure out a better model to 
how galaxies rotate we should never forget that it is a band aid. And it 
remains a band aid until someone proposes a theory what this dark matter 
actually is. Then we can test this new theory and if that works out we can 
fix our estimates of mass of galaxies and maybe then general relativity 
will accurately predict rotation of galaxies. Until then "dark matter" = 
"we dont know why galaxies rotate like they do".
And to the parent, i seriously doubt any scientit is confused about the 
dark matter. Its just a failure of PopSci to explain it, it doesn't make 
good news to report "and here we have no idea what is going on". Science is 
not about what we already know or about making up mysterious answers to 
mysterious questions. Science is about expanding our horizon of ignorance 
as some wiseass put it.
comments.author: r2kordmaa

comments.text: I completely agree.
comments.author: James Briggs

comments.text:
Scientists don't "invent a concept to explain phenomenon". In reality, 
scientists describe physical phenomenon using mathematics. Then they use 
mathematics to make new predictions about the universe. After the 
predictiions are made scientists must test the predictions using 
experimental data etc to confirm whether their theory is valid. 

But there is no experimental data for what dark matter is, only theoretical 
calculations that prove it must be there. The only thing that we know is 
that there is a large amount of matter that humans cannot see, so we call 
it "dark matter". It could be that our telescopes aren't sensitive enough 
so light from dim stars doesn't make the intergalactic journey. It could be 
our mass estimates for the galaxies is fundamentally flawed. Hell, it could 
even be some weird magic particle that for some reason does not interact 
with the electromagnetic spectrum. Nobody actually 100% knows.

People who believe a specific theory about dark matter actually actually do 
share something in common with the religious mans belief in god. They both 
choose to believe something without experimental data to support its 
existence.
comments.author: mikestoneadfjgs

comments.text:
Not at all true. Scientists have a history of discovering things by the 
impact of those things on their surroundings. So you learn a bit by what 
you see and then you guess what might be next then you do an experiment to 
prove or disprove your guess. If the experiment proves your guess was 
correct then you have succeeded in moving the curtain back a bit. If the 
experiment proves your guess was wrong then you re-examine the data and 
make another guess etc. Neptune was discovered in a way which is similar to 
the prediction of the existence of Dark Matter: The following is from wiki 
- The planet Neptune was mathematically predicted before it was directly 
observed. With a prediction by Urbain Le Verrier, telescopic observations 
confirming the existence of a major planet were made on the night of 
September 23–24, 1846,[1] at the Berlin Observatory, by astronomer Johann 
Gottfried Galle (assisted by Heinrich Louis d'Arrest), working from Le 
Verrier's calculations. It was a sensational moment of 19th century science 
and dramatic confirmation of Newtonian gravitational theory. In François 
Arago's apt phrase, Le Verrier had discovered a planet "with the point of 
his pen".
comments.author: Derek Hillard

comments.text:
No. 

The effects of dark matter can be measured and observed along with the 
effects of other stuff. We can't see dark matter itself, but we can 
mathematically and scientifically demonstrate the existence of 'something 
else' and deduce what it is using measurement. Let me give you a basic 
example of how that works. Algebra.

If you have 4 + x = 7, what is x? It's 3. This is how we measure 
darkmatter, we're measuring the unknown by the quantifiable result of the 
whole, and some of its factors. 

When we look at the galaxy, we see a lot more mass in our measurements than 
we see stars the other stuff that would be there. The x, in this case, is 
the extra mass. Let's give what we can see a number, shall we? The stuff we 
can directly observe, we'll give it the number 2. But we have a galaxy that 
weighs 10, and another 2 won't work, 2+2 =/= 10. So even if we double all 
the observable mass in the galaxy, it still doesn't account for all that 
extra mass in the galaxy. There is something there, something we can't see.

We don't rightly know what it is, but based on its effects, particularly 
the gravitational effect it has on the galaxy as a whole, it has to be very 
massive. Because we can't see it, it has to be very dark. So we call it 
'dark matter'. It's a bit of a misnomer because we don't really know what 
it is. Scientists aren't pretending that they know exactly what it is, and 
they could have just called it 'x' if they wanted to, all we know is that 2 
+ dark matter = 10, so we CAN quantify it.

One last example. Get up really early one morning and sit in a dark room 
before sunrise. As the room fills up with light before you've even seen the 
sun that day, ask yourself, where is the light coming from?

The difference with religious postulations of 'god did it' is that god 
can't be quantified. If he could, then we'd be able to demonstrate his 
existence, that's why people ask for evidence of God. But then the 
religious turn around and ADMIT he can't be quantified because he's 
supernatural.... but somehow he has an affect on the natural world. If 
something is having an effect on the natural world, then we'd be able to 
see the effect, even if we couldn't see the source. We'd be able to measure 
it, observe its effects, and quantify its existence, even if we couldn't 
place exactly what 'it' was.

Even if one were to postulate that dark matter = God, it would still be a 
guess, and not even an educated one. When scientists talk about what they 
know, they are not afraid to admit, "we don't know, that's why we're 
investigating, so we can find out." When the religious talk about what they 
know, they say, "the bible says it, it must be true, no need to 
investigate."
comments.author: Remiel Pollard

comments.text:
The comparison would be better if you said Theist Agnostics and Scientists 
are similar in that regard. No way are they similar to religious people.

It is simply a term for something they cannot observe, something that acts 
similarly to visible matter but is invisible. Hence, dark matter. They 
never claim to know what it is, precisely, just that that's what they think 
the data shows. 

A truly religious person will claim to *know* God exists and what He/She/It 
wants depending on their holy book, rather than express any doubt. 
Scientists say there's something we can't see/explain, and named it 'dark 
matter' till further notice. Religious people say there's something we 
can't explain, and then somehow provide you with a history of the cosmos 
that bends physics.

Disclaimer: That's not to say a God doesn't exist, just that I feel it's 
silly to profess anything in the shade of certainty when it comes to 
religion. Personal feelings can't hold a candle to math.
comments.author: paramortalics

comments.text:

they calculated, using mathematics of course, for it to be so. Otherwise 
no, in fact you would have either misunderstand the scientific method so

comments.text:
Dark matter is quite a logical approach to solving this issue, but perhaps 
we've simply still gotten gravity wrong. I think this is a logical 
hypothesis because general relativity does not work on the quantum level 
(Drummed in enough) and unless we assume there is dark matter, it does not 
on the galactic level either. 

This dilemma seems very reminiscent of Newton's Theory of gravity, as it 
was later replaced by Einstein's more accurate General Relativity. Just a 
thought, I'm not fully aware of all the mathematical proof but it seems a 
reasonable hypothesis.﻿

comments.text:
Many people like to make simple comments saying "dark matter is an outdated 
principle that old fashion scientists use to explain why visible matter 
sticks together, but it's not really true". I disagree with this view 
however. Simply because it's so likely that the universe is full of 
particles neither our bodies or technology can possibly detect, but which 
do have an effect on the visible world (such as gravity). Dark matter isn't 
some special particle a scientist came up with, but a term for particles we 
cannot detect but which can have an impact on what we can.﻿

+Katri Lantto
Unfortunately, a very massive black hole that is so massive that the 
effects would have the right strength also has other effects. We would, for 
instance notice tidal forces, the distortion of light paths and very many 
other effects. There is no way in which one massive black hole in the 
center could create the rotational curves that are observed.
Actual calculations (and observations) strongly support a dark matter halo 
around or galaxy (or alternatively: altered laws of gravity and some dark 
matter; though this propositions is rather unlikely).
In reality, the simplest solutions to that problem are indeed dark matter 
particles or dark matter particles + altered laws of gravity. Every simpler 
explanation was already excluded.

comments.text:
Yes, that was one of the ideas a long time ago to explain dark matter. But 
if you look at areas in the sky where you would predict these large black 
holes to be at, you don't find the micro-lenses that they would create if 
they were there (since gravity also affects the path light takes, 
remember?).
There is also a more troubling issue: to have a universe with a matter 
distribution like ours, some form of matter is required that does not at 
all interact with light. You see, in the very early universe the energies 
were high enough for matter to constantly annihilate and produce matter 
again (in the latest phases through annihilation into gamma radiation and 
pair-production from light). This causes a "mixing" of the matter though 
the universe and irons out inhomogeneities. Once the universe cooled down 
enough, this process stopped and the "normal" matter could finally 
accumulate to form galaxies etc. But calculations show that the universe 
was much too homogenous to have this sponge-like structure we observe arise 
on its own by just this process.
This discrepancy can be explained by the presence of dark matter, that does 
not interact with light at all, so it can accumulate and form 
inhomogeneities earlier that the visible matter content. These 
inhomogeneities can then act as gravity wells for the visible matter to 
accumulate in. As far as we can tell so far, this is the best explanation 
for the large scale structure of the universe that we know of.
There is also another problem with black holes as dark matter: there is no 
known process by which this enormous number of black holes could possibly 
be produced. Simple accumulation by gravity would require much longer times 
than the observed age of the universe and also a much more inhomogeneous 
that we find our universe to be.
But that was still a nice idea ;)

comments.author: MusicalRaichu

comments.text:
I love how everyone posting here is acting like they know all the secrets 
to the universe and all the scientists in the world are wrong, particularly 
the people trying to claim dark matter doesn't exist and it's just 
electromagnetism. It's such a sad, sad thing that these people consider 
themselves intelligent. Electromagnetism is the one force of the universe 
we truly understand, and to say it's responsible for dark matter is about 
the single dumbest explanation I have ever heard in my life. We don't know 
*anything* about dark matter, except that it is NOT part of the 
electro-weak-strong forces, as those are all part of the *physical existing 
universe*. That is literally *the only thing we know about dark matter for 
sure* That's about as dumb as saying that *gravity* is caused by 
electromagnetism. It's simply a total separate, completely irrelevant force 
that has nothing to do with the carrying particles of electromagnetism and 
has no relation to electromagnetism whatsoever. Gravity and dark matter 
both exists regardless of the existence of electromagnetic fields, and the 
existence of things like black holes prove this, they have so much gravity 
that they obliterate the carrying particles of electromagnetism, if dark 
matter or gravity were related to electromagnetism, black holes could not 
exist, and we know that their existence is vital to the creation of 
important structures like galaxies that heard stars together so they don't 
flail about randomly smashing into each other.

It's just stupid and wrong. Gravity, Dark Matter, and Dark Energy are all 
part of the *dark universe* or whatever you want to call it, that can not 
be observed or interacted with by the physical universe. These parts of the 
universe are totally separate from mass, energy, particles, and the 
electro-strong-weak forces, which *DO* exist, and can be measured, viewed, 
understood, and studied. We can watch the carrying particles of 
electromagnetism do their thing, and they do what electromagnetism should 
do. If they caused gravity, or dark matter we would have seen it a *LOOOONG 
time ago*... Like seriously, do you think every scientist in the world is a 
complete and total moron who never thought to check if electromagnetism, a 
force they can observe and study in detail was causing other forces of 
nature? In fact, it would be *glaringly obvious* the second we gained the 
ability to study electromagnetism if it was causing dark matter, or dark 
energy, or gravity.

Now if you want to tell me dark matter is caused by gravity in some way, 
then sure, that's debatable, if totally unprovable with no evidence to back 
it up, at least it's within the realm of possibility. But it's more likely 
it's caused by giant elk men in pink tuxedos swinging around jars of 
marmalade at the center of the universe then it is being caused by the 
electro-strong-weak forces. 

But then again, what level of intelligence should I expect from youtubers?﻿

comments.text:
''the strange states of matter when things get close to zero kelvin. Hence 
we have superfluids and super conductors, at these cold temperatures where 
matter has no friction/ heat moves faster and electrons have no resistance 
in conductors.'' +Ross Kennedy  

You are getting close to one observation i made and i have an hypothesis 
for that. But i can't really prove it with mathematics, i'm not skilled 
enough for that, so its all but hypothesis. Yet, i feel like i'm still 
missing something. But i don't think that fondamentally cold or ''the lack 
of movement/low energy state'' of the atoms is what should be focused on to 
understand the big picture. Think of it as a state of someting else, like 
water that can be Liquid, Solid, Vapour but water itself is a state of 
something else, atoms witch is itself a state of energy for example.

It is logic that matter can become super-conductors when in low energy 
state, the molecules stop moving all over the place and become nearly 
still, thus it is easy for electrons to move through them. Like it would be 
easier to drive fast on a new paved road than one filled with holes. But 
that would be too simple an explanation hehe.

Sorry its hard to make myself clear, i usually write and speak in French.

particles with mass have no friction with other particles in the darkness

comments.author: Ross Kennedy

comments.text:
I think, basically this dark matter / dark energy all has something to do 
with vacuum energy and the strange states of matter when things get close 
to zero kelvin. Hence we have superfluids and super conductors, at these 
cold temperatures where matter has no friction/ heat moves faster and 
electrons have no resistance in conductors. Look at some strange stuff from 
NASA’s cold lab space experiments where matter behaving as a wave and 
matter can be summed like two waves. I think to solve the puzzle it’s got 
something to do with the vacuum energy and the very cold and the weird 
super cold states of matter and quantum effects. But only research will 
bring these answers. It will be something strange like vacuum energy 
excites matter or electrons and in the superfluid state they have no 
friction and accelerate until they get to ‘c’ and adding all the excited 
matter up that’s at ‘c’ is what dark matter is. Just a guess by me.
comments.author: Ross Kennedy

comments.text:
+acsapple  Feynman didn't discover Quantum Mechanics. The groundwork for 
that was laid back in the 1920's from the work of Dirac, Bohr, Heisenburg 
and others. Feynman was born in 1918.
comments.author: Michael Carpenter

comments.text:
What are your credentials that grant criticism of physicists worldwide? I 
can certainly get behind that humans don't have a complete understanding of 
how reality works but that doesn't disprove the accuracy of work that has 
already been completed. If someone said they know if you put a DVD disc 
into a DVD player, it'll play the video but they continually said they do 
not know how exactly the player reads the disc's information, would that 
indicate that they don't have an accurate view of reality? Quantum 
Mechanics isn't something to be understood in normal "human" terms. Richard 
Feynman (it's discoverer) said something to this degree himself. And while 
explanations are sometimes not all there, our mathematical understanding of 
Quantum Mechanics is extremely accurate. This is what determines how the 
world is versus how it seems. So could Dark Matter be something that is 
fictitious and put in to better mathematical calculations? Sure. But 
wouldn't you think that the experts in the field would of figured out 
that's what their doing already? Besides, we don't have to see something 
directly to know it exists. Dark matter has gravitational influence on 
visible matter around it and we can observe that.
